subject: A Hawking We Will Go
event: Sleeping in a castle. Spent the morning hawking. Too cool. My head is swimming with ideas for Westeros. One of the falconers recognized me. Even cooler.

comments.article: Now that sounds like my kind of fun.  Keep swimming in those ideas, George!

knowing where you are - if you see the feathered waterford send hello's his way for me please :) totally amazing experience, hope you both loved it! when we visited we did not have any finery for the real meal deal, so we supped (if you can find some hunger following that amazing brekkie spread!) most nights across the moat at Cullens - highly enjoyed. enjoy a well earned break!
That sounds like one of the best days ever. :D

comments.upictitle: Princesa Azula: Stalker!Azula is watching you write pr0n
comments.article:
Woah!!! I am a falconer! :D I am sure it was an amazing experience!
What kind of birds did they have?

for these newbie experiences. They also have peregrine falcons that are used by the owners of the school, and a gorgeous tawny eagle owl named Dingle that I adore. The queen of the Harris Hawks, Rua, hates him, so they have to be very careful on when they take out which birds for multiple visitors. Many pix were taken by yrs. truly. Some day I'll get a flicker account so people can see all the fun we're having on trips.
comments.subject: they were using Harris hawks
Re: they were using Harris hawks
Re: they were using Harris hawks

comments.article:
YAY!! So glad you guys are having fun. Hope you're resting up well too.

Love. Love. Love. xox
I also many times wondered how people in castles were handling with that problem, without a proper insulation. And glass was rather expensive, if available.

In reality, castles were cold and draughty places. Windows were closed off by wooden planks in winter, so to the rooms were dark and without much air circulation. Usually the only warm places would be the kitchen and one smaller room for the ladies with a fireplace (sometimes situated above the kitchen). The great hall would have a fireplace and/or some fire pans as well, but that wasn't enough to get it warm. Rich lords could hang tapestries at the walls, that helped with insulation a bit; and the floor was covered with straw and rushes. But mostly the only way was to dress in layers of wool and - if you could afford it - fur; the beds would also be equipped with a bunch of furs. The one luxury were hot baths.

There's a reason I would pick a place with Roman civilisation for time travel, not the Middle Ages, much as I love visiting old castles (we got plenty in Germany). ;)

...Lest they be lost for ever!

Oh, I forgot, you don't write on the road. Dang it.

(I kid, I kid!)
comments.subject: Write them all down...

comments.article: Wish i were hanging around Ireland, sleeping in castles, falconing, and recognizing GRRM...hey look! there he is!
What kind of hawk?  A Harris Hawk is flown after pigeons, locally, and she's a nervous creature.
You went HAWKING? I am sooooo very jealous.

WOW, George Martin in my home County, what castle did you stay in?
Wish I could have gone to Octocon but i had other commitments. Enjoyed meeting you in Dublin a year ago and hopefully we meet again.

comments.article: Ashford Castle. George sniffs that it wouldn't stand a seige for an hour.

comments.subject: A Hawking We Will Go

comments.article: wow, hawking, that seems awesome XD, a falcon seems like a cool adversary to a raven XD

That has got to be one of the coolest things I've heard in a while. What a dream come true...! Falconry has interested me for quite some time; I'd love to try it out in the future. Sounds like a rejuvenating day, and I'm glad it went well!! :)

Have fun on that side of the globe, George!

Jake Stormoen
comments.subject: Jealous!!

comments.article:
dear Jake:
we miss you.

come home soon.

love,

Parris
comments.subject: Re: Jealous!!

comments.article:
That's awesome!

There's nothing quite like doing the cool stuff for real. And any time you're in Toronto, you're more than welcome to come hang out with your sword-wielding fans here at AEMMA.

It sounds like you had a great time, I look forward to seeing how this inspires your writing in some way down the road. I've read some fantasy that has incorporated falconry but none of it really impressed me all that much. I think its something that would work out pretty well in the Westeros Universe, considering all of the royal hunts that take place.

Hawking sounds like a really fun outdoor activity, and a great way to enjoy the outdoors. I hope that your trip continues to be an enjoyable experience!
Jon needs another bird for his other shoulder.  It's all bare and empty.
comments.subject: A hawk for Lord Snow!

comments.article: I've always wanted to do that. hope you got pictures for us.
comments.subject: awesome.

comments.article: When you have an idea, write it down. I know you've said you only write at home, but just grab a bit of paper, get it down, and keep it for later. I've found that I tend to forget the best ideas if I wait to write them later.
Maybe you should just stay at the castle until the book is done.  For inspirational purposes only, clearly. ;)

John Huston and most of the cast of THE QUIET MAN stayed during location filming. So we're quite inspired already. I keep looking for the ghosts of John Wayne and Ward Bond in the bar late at night.....
comments.subject: this is where

comments.article: Right you are, very cool. What sort of falcon was it?
